questions.text: During an intensive larval survey in a rural village, public health officials inspected 70 houses and found Aedes aegypti larvae in 8 of them. Additionally, a total of 82 containers were examined, and larvae were present in 19 of these containers. Based on these findings, what is the Breteau Index (BI) for this village?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 27.1

 

Explanation:

 

Breteau Index (BI): Number of positive containers per 100 houses inspected in a specific location.

 

BI =No. of positive containers/No. of houses inspected x 100

 

                            = 19*100/ 70

                            = 27.1

 

Educational Objective:

 

BI >20 for any locality is an indication that the locality is dengue sensitive (High risk) and therefore adequate preventive measures should be taken.

 

Ref: Textbook of Community medicine, Rajvir Balwar, 4th ed, pg 582.

questions.text: In a community plagued by vector-borne diseases, public health officials are implementing various control measures to reduce the mosquito population. One of the methods being employed is the removal of Pistia plants from aquatic environments. This intervention specifically targets the reduction of which mosquito species?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Mansonia

 

Explanation:

 

Mansonia mosquito breeds in ponds and lakes containing certain aquatic plants, especially the floating types like Pistia stratiotes and water hyacinth. Their control consists of the removal of those aquatic plants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Some important Points related to mansonia -

 

  • Disease Transmitted - Malayan (Brugian) filariasis, Chikungunya
  • Eggs laids in star shaped clusters
  • Larvae - Siphon tube present; Rest attached to rootlets of plants
  • Main Vector of Brugian Filariasis (India) - Mansonia annulifers, Mansonia uniformis.

 

Reference: Park 26th ed pg 865.

questions.text: In accordance with the International Health Regulations (IHR), a critical aspect of maintaining global public health security involves the implementation of vector control measures at points of entry such as international airports and seaports. To prevent the spread of vector-borne diseases across borders, up to what distance from these facilities should all types of mosquitoes be kept at bay?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 400 meters

 

Explanation:

 

International measures to restrict the spread of especially Yellow Fever (vector: Aedes aegypti) are specified under International Health Regulations (IHRs):

 

Mosquitoes:

 

1. Aircrafts/ships arriving from endemic areas: Aerosol spray to kill insect vectors.


2. Airports/seaports kept free from vector breeding: at least 400 meters around boundary.


3. Aedes aegypti index: kept below 1

 

Travellers:

 

1. Must possess a valid International certificate of vaccination (validity 10 days–Lifelong) against YF before they enter ‘YF receptive areas’


2. If no such certificate available: Quarantine for 6 days (Max I.P of YF) from the date of leaving an infected area


3. If traveller arrives before certificate becomes valid (10 days after vaccination): Then quarantine him till it becomes valid

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flight range of important mosquito vectors in India:

 

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 865.

questions.text: During an entomological survey in a region with a high prevalence of mosquito-borne diseases, a team of researchers collected a sample of mosquitoes for species identification. The collected mosquitoes were smeared, and a microscopic examination was performed to study their morphological features. The team observed that in a majority of the mosquitoes, the maxillary palpi were of equal length to the proboscis. Based on this characteristic, to which of the following species do these mosquitoes most likely belong?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anopheles female

 

Option C:

 

The key feature mentioned in the question is the equal length of the maxillary palpi and proboscis, which is a characteristic feature of Anopheles mosquitoes. This morphological feature helps differentiate Anopheles mosquitoes from other mosquito species, aiding in species identification during entomological surveys it breeds in clean water.

 

 

Inclined at an angle to surface and Spotted wings: Major features

 

Explanation:

 

A. Aedes, B. Culex, and Mansonia - mosquitoes have maxillary palpi that are much shorter than the proboscis.

 

Option A. Aedes Adult:  Stripes on body & legs (TIGER mosquito), have maxillary palpi that are much shorter than the proboscis, breeding on artificial collections of rain water.

 

 

Option B. Culex: ‘Hunch back’ rest; mosquitoes have maxillary palpi that are much shorter than the proboscis, breeding in dirty and polluted water.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adult Mosquito:

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Community medicine, Rajvir Balwar, 4th ed, pg 580.

questions.text: A health inspector is conducting anti-larval activities in a village to control the spread of mosquito-borne diseases. During the inspection, he observed that in most of the containers holding stagnant water, the larvae present have long and narrow respiratory tubes. Which of the following mosquito species do these larvae most likely belong to?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aedes

 

Option A:

 

Aedes mosquito larvae can be identified by their long and narrow respiratory tubes, which is a distinctive feature of this species. The respiratory tube is an extension of the larva’s eighth abdominal segment, and it is used to obtain air from the water surface. Aedes breeds in artificially collected stagnant water. 

 

 

Explanation: 

 

Option B. Anopheles: larva - No siphon tube; Rest parallel to undersurface of water

 

 

Option C. Mansonia: larvae - has Siphon tube; Rest attached to rootlets of plants

 

 

Option D. Culex: larvae - has Siphon tube; Rest perpendicular to undersurface of water

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Community medicine, Rajvir Balwar, 4th ed, pg 580

questions.text: A community living near a marshland is experiencing an increase in mosquito bites, particularly during evening outdoor activities. While these mosquitoes have not been linked to the transmission of any major diseases in the area, their presence is causing significant discomfort and affecting the quality of life of the residents. Based on the description provided, which of the following mosquitoes is commonly referred to as a “nuisance mosquito”?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Culex

 

 Option D.

 

Culex mosquitoes as commonly referred to as “nuisance mosquitoes” due to their prevalence in large numbers and their biting behavior and breeding in polluted/ dirty/drain water.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. Aedes: known as Tiger mosquito

 

Option B. Anopheles: known as Sophisticated mosquito

 

Option C. Mansonia: No such nomenclature

 

Educational Objective:

 

Some important Pointers related to Culex - 

 

  • Nuisance mosquito is Culex
  • Vector of Bancroftian filariasis (India)- Culex quinquefasciatus (C fatigans)
  • Vector for Japanese Encephalitis (India)- Culex tritaeniorhynchus (MC), Culex vishnuii, Culex gelidus
    Vector for west Nile fever: Culex pipiens
  • Disease Transmitted - Culex mosquito Bancroftian Filariasis, Japanese Encephalitis, West Nile fever, Viral arthritis
  • Flight range of culex mosquito - 11 Km
  • Culicine larvae (Culex, Aedes, Mansonia) have a siphon tube. Culex larvae rest perpendicular to undersurface of water
  • Western equine encephalomyelitis virus (WEE virus) is an arbovirus transmitted by mosquitoes of the genera Culex and Culiseta.
  • It can be identified by the presence of unspotted wings and hunched back.
  • Filarial parasite in culex mosquitoes - is an example of Cyclo-developmental transmission, disease agent undergoes only cyclical change in the body of vector. 

 

Reference: PARK 26th ed, pg 865

questions.text: A medical student is studying different modes of disease transmission through vectors in preparation for an upcoming exam. They are particularly interested in understanding the propagative mode of transmission, where the pathogen replicates within the vector before being transmitted to the host. Which of the following is an example of a disease transmitted through the propagative mode?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Propagative: Disease agent undergoes no cyclical change, but multiplies in the body of the vector, transmission is said to be propagative, e.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.
  2. Cyclo-propagative: The disease agent undergoes cyclical change, and multiplies in the body of the arthropod, e.g., malaria parasite in anopheline mosquito.
  3. Cyclo-developmental: The disease agent undergoes cyclical change but does not multiply in the body of the arthropod, e.g., filarial parasite in Culex mosquito and guinea worm embryo in cyclops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propagative Plague, Cyclo-Propagative Malaria, and Cyclo-developmental Filaria are 3 types of biological transmission having multiplication, multiplication + development, development respectively.

 

Park 26th ed pg 862.

questions.text: A healthcare professional is evaluating a patient presenting with fever, headache, and muscle aches, suspecting a possible vector-borne disease. To guide the diagnostic work-up and patient counseling, the healthcare professional aims to identify the primary vector responsible for transmitting West Nile fever. Which of the following is the main vector for transmitting West Nile fever?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Culex Mosquito

 

Explanation:

 

Culex is the primary vector for transmitting West Nile fever.

 

West Nile Fever 

 

Re-occurrence in India reported from Mallapuram, Kerala in March 2021

 

  • Causative agent: West Nile virus - single-stranded RNA virus, family Flaviviridae, genus Flavivirus
  • Transmission:
    • Vector is Culex pipiens (and other Culicine species)
    • Bird–mosquito–bird” transmission cycle
  • Incubation period: 2–14 days
  • Symptoms: 80% asymptomatic, fever, headache, vomiting, rash, encephalitis, meningitis

 

Prevention:

 

  • No vaccine exists for prevention
  • Source reduction
  • Wear long sleeved shirts and long pants
  • Mosquito bed nets, Window and door screens, Insect repellents

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 866.

questions.text: A public health official is implementing vector control strategies in a community to reduce the incidence of vector-borne diseases. They understand that no single method can control vectors effectively and emphasize the importance of integrated vector management. One of the strategies involves proper disposal of sewage and wastewater. This environmental control measure is particularly aimed at controlling the breeding of which of the following vectors?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Culex Mosquito

 

Option B:

 

Abolition of domestic and peri domestic sources of breeding such as cesspools and open ditches; and arrangements should be made for adequate collection, removal and disposal of sewage and wastewater. Culex breeds in dirty and polluted water (Eq. drains)

 

Explanation:

 

Environmental control: SOURCE REDUCTION METHOD - this generally produced permanent results

 

Option D. Aedes mosquito: Environment should be cleaned up and got rid of water holding containers such as discarded tins, empty pots, broken bottles, coconut shells and similar other artificial collections of rain water.

 

Option A. Anopheles mosquito: Their breeding places should be looked for and abolished by appropriate engineering measures such as filling and drainage. It breeds in clean water (tanks on rooftop).

 

Option C. Mansonia mosquito: Aquatic plants to which the larvae attach themselves should be removed or destroyed by herbicides (ponds, lakes)

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Best level of prevention of arthropod-borne diseases is Primordial prevention (e.g- source reduction).

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 866.

questions.text: In a vector control program aimed at reducing the incidence of mosquito-borne diseases, a public health worker is preparing to utilize Paris Green for anti-larval activity. To ensure effectiveness while minimizing potential harm to the environment, the worker needs to know the recommended concentration for application. What is the recommended concentration at which Paris Green should be applied for anti-larval activity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2% dust

 

Explanation:

 

Paris green is applied as 2 percent dust which is prepared by mixing 2 kg of paris green and 98 kg of a diluent such as soapstone powder or slaked lime.

 

PARIS GREEN (COPPER ACETOARSENITE)

 

  • Emerald green, microcrystalline powder.
  • Anti-larval measure, kills mainly Anopheles larvae as they are surface feeders.
  • Bottom-feeding larvae can also be killed when applied as a special granular formulation.
  • The most widely used larvicide for mosquito control.
  • Recommended dose: 2 percent dust applied in a dose of 1 kg per hectare water surface - 

In the dosage applied, Paris Green does not harm fish, man, or domestic animals

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paris green is a stomach poison (chemical larvicide). Recommended dose is 2 percent dust applied in a dose of 1 kg per hectare water surface. 

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 866.

questions.text: In an effort to quickly reduce the population of adult mosquitoes during an ongoing outbreak of a vector-borne disease, a local health department is considering the use of various insecticides for space spraying. Which of the following insecticides is commonly used for space spraying to target adult mosquitoes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pyrethrum extract

 

Explanation:

 

Space sprays (anti-adult measures):

 

  • Pyrethrum extract: ‘nerve poison’; Active principal ‘pyrethrin’; no residual action–shortlived effect.
  • Residual insecticides: Malathion and fenitrothion for ULV (Ultra low volume) fogging.

 

Pyrethrum:

 

  • Space spray for killing adult mosquitoes
  • Contact poison
  • Knock-down effect with paralysis
  • Insecticide of plant origin: Flowers of Chrysanthemum
  • 5 active principles (all ‘nerve poisons’) - 

 

  • Pyrethrin I
  • Pyrethrin II
  • Cinerin I
  • Cinerin II
  • Jasmoline II

 

  • No residual effect: Short-lived effect
  • Synthetic pyrethroids: permethrin, allethrin, furethrin, cyclethrin
  • Because of the natural insecticidal properties used as ‘companion plants’, to repel pest insects from nearby crops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyrethrum extract is a commonly used insecticide for space spraying to quickly reduce adult mosquito populations during outbreaks, enhancing rapid response efforts in vector control programs. A nerve poison and Active principal is pyrethrin. 

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 867

questions.text: A public health worker is educating a community about the potential health risks associated with houseflies and their role in disease transmission. In order to provide accurate information, the public health worker needs to clarify which of the following is NOT a mode of transmission for diseases carried by houseflies?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Bite

 

Explanation:

 

Houseflies transmit diseases by following methods

 

  1. Mechanical method
  2. Vomit drop
  3. Defecation.

 

HOUSEFLY

 

  • Regarded as a "sign of insanitation" (and their number as Index of sanitation)
  • Important species: Musca domestica, M. vicinia, M. nebula, M. sorbens
  • Life span: 15-25 days
  • Important breeding places (in order of importance): Fresh horse manure, Human excreta, Manure of other animals, Garbage.

 

Feeding habits:

 

  • Housefly does not bite: It cannot eat solid foods; it vomits on solid foods to make a solution of it, and sucks in a liquid state.
  • Dispersal: up to 4 miles
  • Houseflies in disease causation:
  • As vector of diseases: Typhoid and paratyphoid fevers, diarrhoeas and dysenteries, cholera and gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic manifestations, Poliomyelitis, Yaws, Anthrax, Trachoma, conjunctivitis
  • As causative agent of disease: Myiasis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Housefly does not bite; Transmit diseases by Mechanical method, Vomit drop and Defecation.

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 868.

questions.text: A medical student is studying entomology as part of their coursework on infectious diseases. During a practical session, they are shown various insects under a microscope and asked to identify them based on their morphological features. The student observes an insect with hairy features and lanceolate-shaped wings. Based on these characteristics, the student should identify this insect as belonging to which of the following groups?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sand fly

 

Explanation:

 

The wings of sandfly are upright, lanceolate /flame-shaped and densely hairy. Legs twice as long as body

 

 

Sand Fly (Phlebotomus argentipes)

 

  • Habitats: Holes and crevices in walls, holes in trees, dark rooms, stables and store rooms
  • Flight range of Sandfly is 50 yards
  • Sanitation measures are carried out for a distance of 50 feet
  • Insecticide of choice: DDT (1–2 gm/m2 single application)
  • DDT is sprayed upto height of 4–6 feet of walls: as Sandfly cannot fly; it only hops
  • Only female sandflies bite: Require a blood meal every 3-4 days for oviposition. Sandflies inject the infective stage,     metacyclic promastigotes, during blood meals.

 

  • Sandfly is the vector of: –
    • Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala azar)
    • Cutaneous Leishmaniasis (Oriental Sore)
    • Sandfly Fever
    • Oroya Fever
    • Chandipura virus
    • Changuinola virus
    • Naplesvirus
    • Toscana virus
    • Sicilian virus
    • Puntatora virus
    • Vesicular stomatitis
    • Turkey virus
    • Cyprus virus

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic features of sandflies, including their hairy appearance and lanceolate-shaped wings, to aid in the identification of potential vectors for leishmaniasis.

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 869

questions.text: A patient in a rural area of a developing country presents with prolonged fever, substantial weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia. A physician suspects visceral leishmaniasis (Kala-azar) and understands the importance of vector control in preventing the spread of this disease. To implement effective control measures, it is crucial to know the vector responsible for transmitting Kala-azar. Which of the following insects transmits Kala-azar through its bite?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Phlebotomus

 

Explanation: 

 

Sandfly is the vectors responsible for transmitting the protozoan parasites that cause Kala-azar. 

 

Some Important Pointers - 

 

  • Sandflies (Phlebotomus) have not demonstrated resistance to DDT
  • SANDFLY (PHLEBOTOMUS) identification features - Legs twice as long as body; Lanceolate (Flame shaped) wings and Fine hairs on the margins of wings

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Park 26th ed pg 870

questions.text: A team of public health workers is conducting an adult mosquito survey in an urban slum to identify the predominant mosquito species and assess the risk of vector-borne diseases. During their survey, they observed that the majority of the captured mosquitoes have striped bodies. Based on this characteristic feature, which of the following mosquito species is most likely to be prevalent in this area?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Aedes

 

Explanation:

 

Aedes mosquitoes are sometimes referred to as tiger mosquitoes, Because of the striped or banded character of their legs.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aedes mosquitoes are referred to as tiger mosquitoes, Because of the striped or banded character of their legs.

 

Reference: Park 26th ed pg 865.

questions.text: A town is experiencing an increase in cases of vector-borne diseases, and public health officials are working to identify the source and reduce the risk of further transmission. As part of this effort, they are evaluating the local mosquito populations to determine their potential role in disease transmission. Regarding the Culex mosquito species, which is known to transmit diseases such as West Nile virus and lymphatic filariasis, what is the typical flight range of this mosquito?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 11 kms

 

Explanation:

 

Culex Mosquito's flight range is 11 Km

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flight range of important vectors in India: 

 

  • Anopheles - 3-5 Km
  • Culex - 11 Km 
  • Aedes - 100 m (110 yards)
  • Mansonia - 1-2 km
  • Sand fly - 50 yards
  • Simulium (Black fly) - 100 miles (161 Km)

 

Reference: Park 26th ed pg 865.

questions.text: A clinician in a tropical region is evaluating patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of vector-borne diseases. To aid in diagnosis and subsequent management, the clinician is considering the behavior of different mosquito species. Which mosquito species is characteristically known for biting primarily around midnight?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Culex

 

Explanation:

 

Culex is highly anthrophilic. It enters the houses at dusk and reaches maximum density by midnight. The peak biting time is about midnight. Legs, particularly below the knee are the preferred biting sites. During the day, it may be seen resting indoors on walls, underneath.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Culex is the midnight biter or night-time biter 

 

Nuisance mosquito is Culex.

 

Park 26th ed pg 865.

questions.text: A community health officer is exploring various options for controlling mosquito larvae in a waterlogged area to prevent vector-borne diseases. One of the chemicals under consideration is Paris Green. The health officer is interested in understanding the mechanism through which Paris Green exerts its larvicidal effects. How does Paris Green function in the control of mosquito larvae?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Stomach poison

 

Explanation:

 

Paris green is a stomach poison (chemical larvicide). Paris green kills mainly the Anopheles larvae because they are surface-feeders.

PARIS GREEN (COPPER ACETOARSENITE)

 

  • Emerald green, microcrystalline powder (Copper aceto-arsenite)
  • Anti-larval measure, kills mainly Anopheles larvae as they are surface feeders.
  • Bottom-feeding larvae can also be killed when applied as a special granular formulation.
  • The most widely used larvicide for mosquito control
    not harm fish, man, or domestic animals.
  • Recommended dose: 2 percent dust applied in a dose of 1 kg per hectare water surface - In the dosage applied,  Paris Green does

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paris green is a stomach poison (chemical larvicide).

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 866.

questions.text: In a malaria-endemic region, a public health campaign is underway to distribute mosquito nets to the community as a preventive measure against mosquito-borne illnesses. A public health official is tasked with ensuring the quality of the mosquito nets before finalizing the order for distribution. To confirm that the nets will serve as an effective barrier against mosquito bites, the official needs to check the size of the holes in the sample nets. What is the maximum size that the holes in the mosquito net should be to ensure effectiveness against mosquito bites?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 0.0475 inch

 

Explanation:

 

Personal protection measures (against mosquito bites):

  • Mosquito nets:
  • No. of holes per square inch: 150
  • Size of each hole diameter: < 0.0475 inch
  • Screening:

 

Size: 16 meshes to inch

 Aperture size: < 0.0475 inch

 

Insecticide-treated bed nets (ITBN): Chemicals used in ITBN Program: Synthetic pyretheroids (NVBD CP)

 

  1. Deltamethrin: 2.5 % in dosage of 25 mg/m2
  2. Cyfluthrin: 5 % in dosage of 50 mg/m2
  3. Other insecticides used: Permethrin, Lambdacyhalothrin, Etofenprox, -cypermethrin.

 

  • Effectiveness of pyretheroids: 6-12 months (Retreatment every 6 months)
  • Long-lasting insecticidal mosquito nets (LLINs): Also use pyrethroid insecticides, and a chemical binder that allows the nets to be washed ≥20 times, allowing use for ≥3 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mosquito nets are used as personal protection measures: 

 

  • Maximum recommended size of holes in mosquito nets - 0.0475 inch
  • Maximum recommended no. of holes in mosquito nets - 150/sq.inch

 

MC chemical used for Insecticide treated bed nets - Synthetic pyretheroids (effectiveness 6-12 months)

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 867

questions.text: A public health officer is evaluating the sanitary conditions of a community. The officer knows that the presence of certain insects can serve as an indicator of poor sanitation. Which of the following insects is commonly considered as an index of insanitation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. House fly

 

Explanation:

 

HOUSEFLY

 

  • Regarded as a "sign of insanitation" (and their number as Index of sanitation).
  • Important species: Musca domestica, M. vicinia, M. nebula, M. sorbens
  • Life span: 15-25 days
  • Important breeding places (in order of importance): Fresh horse manure, Human excreta, Manure of other animals, Garbage
  • Feeding habits:
    • Housefly does not bite: It cannot eat solid foods; it vomits on solid foods to make a solution of it, and sucks in a liquid state.
    • Dispersal: up to 4 miles
  • Houseflies transmit diseases by following methods

 

  1. Mechanical method
  2. Vomit drop
  3. Defecation

 

  • Houseflies in disease causation:
    • As vector of diseases: Typhoid and paratyphoid fevers, diarrhoeas and dysenteries, cholera and gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic manifestations, Poliomyelitis, Yaws, Anthrax, Trachoma, conjunctivitis
    • As a causative agent of disease: Myiasis

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Housefly is a "sign of insanitation" (and their number as Index of sanitation).

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 868

questions.text: A researcher is classifying various organisms based on their taxonomic categories. She has listed several organisms under the class Insecta. Which of the following organisms does not belong to the class Insecta?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hard tick

 

Option B:

 

Ticks and mites belonged to class Arachnida 

 

Explanation:

 

Other 3 options (A. Mosquitos, C. Fleas and D. bed bugs) belonged to class Insecta.

 

Educational objective:

 

Arthropods of Medical Importance :

 

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 861

questions.text: A public health officer is investigating a region with a high incidence of vector-borne diseases. As part of the investigation, the officer is studying the breeding habits of different mosquito species to implement effective control measures. Upon examination of a water body, the officer observes that there are several clusters of eggs floating on the surface of the water, appearing as if they are laid together in rafts. Based on this observation, which of the following mosquito species is most likely responsible for laying these eggs?
questions.solution:
Ans.  C. Culex

 

Option C:

 

Culex mosquitoes are known to lay their eggs in the form of rafts, where hundred's of eggs are laid together in a floating cluster on the surface of stagnant or still water. This is a distinctive breeding habit of Culex mosquitoes and helps in identifying their breeding sites for vector control measures.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mansonia: Mansonia mosquitoes lay their eggs on under surface of leaves of aquatic plants in Star-shaped cluster 

 

 

Option B. Anopheles:  Anopheles mosquitoes lay their eggs singly on the surface of water, boat-shaped eggs with lateral floats

 

 

Option D. Aedes: Aedes mosquitoes also lay their eggs singly (Cigar shaped), but they prefer to lay them just above the water line in areas that are prone to flooding.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Culex mosquitoes based on their distinctive egg-laying behavior of forming egg rafts, and differentiate them from other mosquito species based on their breeding habits.

 

Ref: Textbook of Community medicine, Rajvir Balwar, 4th ed, pg 580

choices.text: 10
5
7.5
2.5

questions.text: A public health team is conducting a larval survey in a tropical region during the peak mosquito breeding season. The aim is to assess the risk of dengue fever transmission in various residential areas. They calculate the House Index (HI) based on the number of houses inspected and the number of houses found to have Aedes mosquito larvae or pupae. Which of the following HI thresholds should the team use to categorize an area as being sensitive to a dengue outbreak?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 5

 

Explanation:

 

Indices of Surveillance of Aedes Mosquitoes - 

 

House Index (HI): Percentage of houses or premises positive for Aedes larvae.

 

        HI = (No. of houses positive for Aedes larvae/ No. of houses inspected) x 100

 

Container Index (CI): Percentage of water-holding containerspositive for Aedes larvae.

    

    CI = (No. of positive containers/No. of containers inspected) x 100

 

Breteau Index (BI): Number of positive containers per 100 houses in a specific location.

     

   BI = (No. of positive containers/ No. of houses inspected) x 100

 

HI >5% &/or a BI >20 for any locality is an indication that the locality is dengue sensitive and therefore adequate preventive measures should be taken.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An area is considered sensitive to a dengue outbreak if the House Index, which measures the percentage of houses infested with Aedes mosquito larvae or pupae, is more than 5%.

 

Ref: Textbook of Community medicine, Rajvir Balwar, 4th ed, pg 582

questions.text: A public health professional is educating a community about the risks associated with Aedes mosquito bites and the diseases they transmit. To enhance their awareness and preventive practices, it is crucial to accurately identify the diseases associated with this vector. Which of the following diseases is NOT typically transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Japanese encephalitis

 

Option C:

 

Aedes mosquitoes transmit several viral diseases including Dengue fever, Zika virus, and Chikungunya, they are not vectors for Japanese Encephalitis, which is primarily transmitted by Culex mosquito. 

 

Explanation:

 

Other 3 options A. Dengue, B. Chikungunya and D. Rift Valley fever are transmiited by Aedes mosquito

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref:Park 26th ed pg 866.

questions.text: A public health official is studying the lifecycle of disease agents within arthropod vectors to better understand the transmission dynamics of vector-borne diseases. The official is particularly interested in the duration of time that the disease agent takes to develop within the arthropod host before it becomes infectious to humans. What is the term used to describe this period of development?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extrinsic incubation period

 

Explanation:

 

The extrinsic incubation period (EIP) (Sporogony) refers to the time required for the development of the disease agent within the arthropod vector before it becomes infectious to humans or other vertebrate hosts. This period is crucial for understanding the transmission dynamics of vector-borne diseases and implementing effective control measures. 

 

  • EIP of Plasmodium: Period for development of parasite from Gametocyte to Sporozoite stage in body of mosquito. EIP is around 10-20 days
  • Aedes mosquitoes become infective by feeding on a patient from the day before onset to the 5th day (viraemia stage) of illness: After an extrinsic incubation period of 8-10 days, the mosquitoes become infective. 

 

Educational objective:

 

The extrinsic incubation period is the time taken by an organism to develop in the intermediate host. For example, once ingested by a mosquito, malaria parasites must undergo development within the mosquito before they are infectious to humans.

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 862.

questions.text: A community in a malaria-endemic region is implementing vector control measures to reduce the transmission of the disease. The local health department decided to conduct residual spraying using Malathion at a concentration of 2 grams per square meter. The community health workers are interested in knowing how long this intervention will remain effective in controlling the adult mosquito population. For how long does one round of residual spraying with 2 grams/square meter of Malathion act as an effective anti-adult measure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 3 months

 

Explanation:

 

Anti-adult measures:

 

Residual sprays:

                            ​​​​​​​    ​​​​​​​    ​​​​​​​ 

 

(OMS = Ortho-Isopropoxyphenyl-Methylcarbonate)

 

Space sprays:

 

  • Pyrethrum extract: ‘nerve poison’; Active principal ‘pyrethrin’; no residual action–shortlived effect.
  • Residual insecticides: Malathion and fenitrothion for ULV (Ultra low volume) fogging

 

Genetic control:

 

  • Sterile male technique
  • Cytoplasmic incompatibility
  • Chromosomal translocations
  • Sex distortion
  • Gene replacement

 

Educational objective:

 

One round of residual spraying with 2 grams/square meter of Malathion is generally effective for up to 3 months in controlling adult Anopheles mosquitoes, contributing to the reduction of malaria transmission in endemic regions.

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 867.

choices.text: Oriental sore
Chagas disease
Kala azar
Papatasii fever

questions.text: A clinician is reviewing the different vector-borne diseases in preparation for a medical mission in a tropical region. To provide accurate prevention and treatment strategies, it is vital to identify the vectors responsible for transmitting various diseases. Which of the following diseases is NOT transmitted by sandflies?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Chagas disease

 

Option B:

 

Chagas disease (Sleeping sickness of America) is transmitted by Reduviid bug (Kissing bug).

 

Reduviid bugs (Triatominae) – Also known as ‘Cone–nose bugs’ or ‘Kissing bugs’ or ‘Assassin bugs’. Vectors of Chagas’ Disease (American Trypanosomiasis ‘Sleeping sickness of America’), caused by Trypanosoma cruzi.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oriental Sore:  Cutaneous Leishmaniasis transmited by Phlebotomus papatasii and Phlebotomus sergenti species. 

 

Option C. Kala Azar: Visceral Leishmaniasis is transmited by Phlebotomus argentipes species

 

Option D. Papatasii fever:  Is transmited by Phlebotomus papatasii species

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 870.

choices.text: Black fly
Tsetse fly
Sand fly

questions.text: A 35-year-old man residing in a rural area of sub-Saharan Africa presents to a healthcare facility with intermittent fever, headaches, and generalized weakness for the past several weeks. The healthcare provider suspects a vector-borne disease and recalls that a specific organism is known to transmit the causative agent of this condition in the region. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for acting as a vector for the patient’s suspected condition, trypanosomiasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tsetse fly

 

Explanation:

 

Tsetse flies (Glossina palpalis) are vectors of trypanosomiasis or “sleeping sickness”. The disease affects man, domestic animals, and wild game - being particularly lethal to man, and his domestic stock.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 870

questions.text: In an advanced entomology session focused on the life cycles of various insects, the professor discusses how certain insects have unique developmental stages. Some of these insects do not experience a pupal stage during their growth. Considering this information, which of the following organisms can be identified as lacking a pupal stage in its life cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Louse

 

Explanation:

 

Three stages in the life history of lice: egg, larva/Nymph and adult.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

LICE (singular LOUSE) - 

 

Wingless insects, also known as ‘Fly babies’

 

Lice as the vectors of diseases:

 

  • Epidemic typhus (Rickettsia prowazekii)
  • Relapsing fever (Borrelia recurrentis)
  • Trench fever (Rickettsia Quintana)
  • Pediculosis capitis (head), corporis (body)
  • Dermatitis (Due to scratching and secondary infection)

 

Mode of transmission of Epidemic Typhus: (IS NOT BY LOUSE-BITE)

 

  • Scratching and inoculation with infected louse faeces.
  • Crushing infected louse on body.
  • Inhalation of infected louse faeces or dust.

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 871

choices.text: Trench fever
Relapsing fever
Epidemic typhus
Oriental sore

questions.text: Having recently attended a lecture on vector-borne diseases, with a focus on diseases transmitted by lice, you are now tasked with identifying which of the following diseases is not typically transmitted by lice. Choose the correct option from the list below.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Oriental sore

 

Option D:

 

Causative agent of Cutaneous Leshmaniasis (Oriental Sore) - Leishmania tropica.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Trench fever:  Bartonella quintana infection (historically called ‘trench fever’) is a vector-borne disease primarily transmitted by the human body louse Pediculus humanus.

 

Option B. Relapsing Fever:  Caused by Borrelia recurrentis and transmitted by louse

 

Option C. Epidemic typhus: Caused by Rickettsia prowazekii and transmitted by louse

 

Educational Objective:

 

While lice are vectors for diseases such as epidemic typhus, trench fever, and relapsing fever, they are not vectors for Oriental Sore, which is typically transmitted by sand fly. 


Ref: Park 26th ed pg 871

questions.text: As part of a public health initiative, a team is conducting fieldwork to understand and control vector-borne diseases in a specific region. A medical student on the team is tasked with gathering information about sandfly behavior to better target prevention efforts. The student needs to determine the typical range within which sandflies stay close to their breeding sites. What distance from their breeding places do sandflies generally confine themselves to?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 50 Yards

 

Explanation:

 

Flight range

 

Sandfly - 50 yards

 

Anopheles - 3-5 Km

 

Culex - 11 Km

 

Aedes - 100 m (110 Yards)

 

Mansonia - 1-2 km

 

Simulium (Black fly) - 100 miles (161 Km)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flight range of Sandfly is 50 yards.

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 870

choices.text: Tsetse fly
Reduviid bugs
Black fly
Sand flea

questions.text: A 35-year-old man from a rural area in South America presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, fever, and swelling around his left eye. On further examination, the physician notes an enlarged liver and spleen. Suspecting a vector-borne disease, the physician inquires about the patient’s living conditions and exposure to insects. To identify the vector responsible for transmitting the disease that the patient might be suffering from, the physician should recognize that Chagas disease is transmitted by?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Reduviid bugs

 

Explanation: 

 

Reduviid bugs live exclusively in the blood of animals including man and transmit Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas’ disease.

 

 

Reduviid bugs (Triatominae):  Also known as ‘Cone–nose bugs’ or ‘Kissing bugs’ or ‘Assassin bugs'

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 874

choices.text: Hard ticks feed continuously and cannot withstand starvation.
Dorsal aspect of soft tick is covered with scutum
Soft ticks can withstand starvation for months

questions.text: During a Demonstration session on vector-borne diseases, a mentor is emphasizing the importance of accurately identifying and understanding the characteristics of various vectors. The discussion turns to ticks, and the mentor presents a specimen, asking the participants about the characteristics of hard and soft ticks. Which of the following statements is incorrect about ticks?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Dorsal aspect of soft tick is covered with scutum

 

Explanation: 

 

  • The hard ticks are covered on their dorsal surface by a chitinous shield, called scutum- In male it covers the entire back, and in the female only a small part in front. The scutum or dorsal shield is absent in soft ticks.
  • Hard ticks have a “head” or capitulum at anterior end; soft ticks have a head on under side, which is entirely invisible from above.
  • The males are generally smaller than females.
  • The hard ticks feed both night and day and cannot stand starvation; the soft ticks, on the other hand, feed at night and can withstand starvation for several months.
  • The hard ticks are always found on their hosts; the soft ticks hide in cracks and crevices during the day and emerge at night to feed on the host.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disease Transmitted - Hard Vs Soft Ticks

 

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 874

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer from a rural area in Maharashtra, India, presents to a local health clinic with complaints of fever, headache, and a painful swelling on his right leg. He reports finding a small creature attached to his leg a few days ago, which he removed manually. On examination, there is an erythematous rash around the site and regional lymphadenopathy. The physician is considering a vector-borne disease and needs to determine the most likely mode of transmission related to the patient’s exposure. Trans-stadial transmission, where a pathogen is transmitted from one life stage to the next within a vector, is characteristic of which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ticks

 

Explanation:

 

Trans-stadial transmission: Agent transmitted from nymph to adult vector – Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

 

Trans-ovarial transmission (vertical transmission): Female vector passes the infectious agent through her eggs to the next generation – Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trans-stadial transmission is seen in Ticks.

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 875

questions.text: A 34-year-old wildlife researcher working in a forested area in India presents to the clinic with high fever, severe headache, and fatigue. She recalls being bitten by a tick two weeks ago while conducting fieldwork. The physician is concerned about possible tick-borne diseases and starts considering various differential diagnoses. Which of the following diseases is NOT typically transmitted by hard ticks?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Q fever

 

Option D.

 

Q fever is only rickettsial Disease without any vector: only in few animal cases, soft tick is the vector. It is caused by Coxiella burnetii.  It is transmited by aerosol/respiratory mode of transmission.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rocky Mountain spotted fever:  Cused by Rickettsia rickettsii, Rodents reservoir and vector hard tick.

 

Option B. Tularaemia:  Bacterial disesae transmitted by Hard tick.

 

Option C. Human Babesiosis: transmitted by Hard tick.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diseases transmitted by Hard tick Vs Soft Tick - 

 

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 875

choices.text: Red squill
Zinc phosphide
Barium carbonate

questions.text: In an urban area in India experiencing a significant rodent infestation problem, the local public health department is exploring various strategies for rodent control. The team is considering the use of rodenticides and is discussing the options available. They are aware that some rodenticides act acutely, quickly killing the rodents, while others have a delayed effect. Which of the following is NOT considered an acute rodenticide?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Coumatetralyl

 

Options D:

 

Coumatetralyl is an anticoagulant of the 4-hydroxycoumarin vitamin K antagonist type, used as a rodenticide. But not the acute type, need continuous exposure for few days to show strong toxic effects. 

 

Rodenticides- Pest control chemicals intended to kill rodents
 

Anticoagulants: 4-hydroxy coumarin

 

  • Phosphides: Zinc phosphide, aluminium phosphide
  • Calciferols: Vitamin D
  • Others: ANTU (a–naphthylurea), arsenic, barium, thallium, strychnine

 

Explanation:

 

Other 3 options are acute rodenticides: They kill the rodents on ingestion of a single dose of the toxic bait. Includes Red squill (option A), bromide, sodium fluoroacetate, Strychnine, ANTU, Zinc phosphide (Option B), Barium carbonate (Option C), etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rodenticides dangerous to use: Arsenic trioxide, Phosphorus, Thallium sulphate, ANTU, Gophacide.

 

Ref: Textbook of community medicine by Rajvir Balwar, 4th ed pg 604

choices.text: Epidemic typhus
Murine typhus

questions.text: A 30-year-old researcher is working in a laboratory in India, studying various vector-borne diseases. She is currently focused on diseases transmitted by fleas and is trying to compile a comprehensive list of such diseases. She is aware that fleas are responsible for transmitting a variety of bacterial, viral, and rickettsial diseases. However, she is unsure about which diseases are not transmitted by fleas. Which of the following infections is NOT typically transmitted by fleas?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Epidemic typhus

 

Option A:

 

Epidemic Typhus is a type of rickettsial disease of typhus group; causative agent is R. prowazekii. Vector is Louse (P. capitis, P. corporis); mode of transmission IS NOT BY LOUSE-BITE, but due to Scratching and inoculation with infected louse faeces, Crushing infected louse on body, Inhalation of infected louse faeces or dust.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Murine typhus: Caused by R. typhi and transmitted by rat flea.

 

Option C. Plague: Rat flea act as a vector for Bubonic plague.

 

Option D. Chiggerosis: Rat flea transmit the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RAT FLEA (XENOPSYLLA):

 

 

Rat flea acts as a vector for:

 

  •  Bubonic plague
  •  Murine (endemic/flea-borne) typhus
  •  Chiggerosis


Rat flea acts as a host for:

 

  •  Hymenolepis diminuta (Rat tapeworm)
  •  Hymenolepis nana (Dwarf tapeworm)

 

Ref: Textbook of community medicine by Rajvir Balwar, 4th ed pg599.

choices.text: Females are larger than males
Both sexes thrive on blood.
Larva and nymph don’t feed on blood
Soft tick lacks festoons

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of camping in the woods presents to the clinic with a fever, headache, and muscle aches that started a week ago. On examination, there is a noticeable red, expanding rash with a central clearing on his thigh. The patient recalls being bitten by a small insect but did not pay much attention to it. He is concerned as his symptoms have been progressively worsening. The physician suspects a vector-borne disease and decides to investigate further the potential vectors involved in this region. Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding the suspected vector in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Larva and nymph don’t feed on blood.

 

Option C.

 

In Ticks- Both sexes as well as the other stages i.e., nymph and larvae thrive on blood alone and lead an intermittent parasitic life during a major part of their life cycle.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. Females are larger than males: Correct

 

Option B. Both sexes thrive on blood: Correct 

 

Option D. Soft ticks are devoid of scutum or festoons: Correct

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hard Tick Vs Soft Tick 

 

 

Ref: Textbook of community medicine by Rajvir Balwar, 4th ed pg 595.

questions.text: A 28-year-old architect is designing a new office building and is keen on ensuring that the indoor environment promotes comfort and well-being for future occupants. She understands that thermal comfort is a critical aspect of indoor environmental quality. To achieve this, she decides to consider various indices that reflect thermal comfort. She recalls some of the indices from her college days but is unsure about one particular index. Which of the following is NOT an index of thermal comfort?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Soiling index

 

Option C:

 

Soiling Index - is a Chemical indicator of air pollution

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cooling power: Air temperature, humidity and air movement.

 

Option B. Effective temperature: the effect of temperature, humidity and movement of the internal air on the sensation of warmth or cold felt by the human body.

 

Option D. McArdle’s Maximum allowable sweat rate: 4.5 litres for 4 hours. Maximum 3 liters per hour for comfort zone.

 

 

Other Indices of Thermal Comfort 

 

  1. Air temperature.
  2. Air temperature and humidity.
  3. Corrected Effective Temperature (CET) is an index of thermal comfort that combines the effect of temperature, humidity, velocity of air & mean radiant heat. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kata thermometer readings as indices of thermal comfort: Kata thermometer measures ‘cooling power of air’ - which is comprises of Air temperature, Humidity and Air movement (Nowadays it is used to record low air velocity mainly)

 

  • Dry kata reading > 6 (Thermal comfort)
  • Wet kata reading > 20 (Thermal comfort)

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 826
